subject: Art
title: Color & Branding
description: How businesses use color psychology to shape perception.

hook.text: Coca-Cola is red. Facebook is blue. Starbucks is green. These aren't random choices â€” each color was selected to trigger specific associations in consumers' minds.

buildup.text: Blue dominates tech and finance (trust, reliability). Red owns food and entertainment (energy, appetite). Green claims health and nature. Black signals luxury. Each industry clusters around colors that match its values.

discovery.text: Color increases brand recognition by up to 80%. People make subconscious judgments about products within 90 seconds, and up to 90% of that assessment is based on color alone.

twist.text: The best brands sometimes break convention: T-Mobile uses magenta in a sea of blue telecoms. Standing out can be more powerful than fitting in â€” if you're strategic about it.

climax.text: Pick any brand you love. Why that color? How would the brand feel if it were a completely different color? Imagine McDonald's in purple. The strangeness proves how deeply color shapes identity.

punchline.text: Color is a brand's first impression. Choose it as carefully as a company name.

quiz.question: Why does blue dominate tech and finance branding?
options: It's the cheapest color to print
